s.text: Laser densitometry was performed using a Molecular Dynamics Storm scanner system (Molecular Dynamics, Inc., Sunny vale, CA).
All plates were scraped and contents were transferred to 50 ml conical tubes.

Our findings suggest that RSV induction of chemokine gene expression involves a redox-sensitive NF-?B signaling mechanism that differs from that mediated by TNF? and involving predominantly the Rel A subunit of NF-?B.
However, the inhibitory effects were most striking for Rel A suggesting the inhibitors primarily target the RSV induction of Rel A.

RSV infection in infancy cause severe bronchiolitis and pneumonia and may predispose children to the subsequent development of asthma, the most common chronic illness of childhood [ 1 ] . Many studies have indicated that chemokines can play an important role in the onset and severity of asthma and it has been shown that RSV infection of lung epithelial cells increases chemokine production, although the mechanisms involved are largely unknown [ 2 3 4 5 ] .
Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) belongs to the Pneumovirinae subfamily of the Paramyxovirodae family of enveloped single-stranded negative sense RNA viruses.
The virus and cells were incubated for 2 hours, after which DMEM was added to bring culture to normal growth volume and 7% FBS.
To demonstrate binding specificity, 100-fold molar excess (10 ng) of a specific or non-specific oligonucleotide (5'-ATTCGATCGGGGCGGGGCGAGC-3') was included in the binding reaction.
In addition, TNF? was also able to induce p50 by about 5-fold whereas RSV increased the constitutive p50 level by only about 50%.
3, the two inhibitors had very different effects on chemokine gene expression.
